title: 103_s1683
content: The Sterling Forest and New Jersey Watershed Protection Act of 1993 allows for land acquisition. The Palisades Park Commission is authorized to acquire an open space tract of land from the Sterling Forest Corporation in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands Region. The Commission will manage the acquired land to enhance protection of watersheds, outdoor recreation, wildlife habitat, and Appalachian Trail values in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands. The Palisades Park Commission is authorized to acquire open space in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands Region for recreational, wildlife habitat, and Appalachian Trail values. The Sterling Forest Protection Act of 1994 authorizes appropriations for acquiring land described in section 2 and allows for the transfer of funds to the Commission to carry out the Act. This Act may be cited as the "Sterling Forest Protection Act of 1994". The Palisades Interstate Park Commission manages 23 parks and historic sites in New York and New Jersey, totaling over 82,000 acres. Sterling Forest, a biologically diverse area on the New Jersey border, covers approximately 17,500 acres and serves as a significant watershed for the state. Over 8 million visitors annually enjoy outdoor recreational opportunities within the Palisades Park System. Sterling Forest, located on the New Jersey border, covers 17,500 acres and is a vital watershed area providing clean drinking water for 25% of the state. It supports a variety of habitats and rare species, enhances the Appalachian National Scenic Trail, and offers recreational opportunities in a densely populated region. The Sterling Forest covers 17,500 acres on the New Jersey border, serving as a vital watershed area providing clean drinking water for 25% of the state. It supports various habitats, rare species, and enhances the Appalachian National Scenic Trail, offering recreational opportunities in a densely populated region. The protection of Sterling Forest through the Palisades Interstate Park Commission will involve minimal Federal funds due to stewardship costs being covered by New York and New Jersey. The nationally significant watershed, outdoor recreational, and wildlife qualities of Sterling Forest, along with the demand for open space in the northeastern United States, highlight a clear Federal interest in acquiring the forest for permanent protection. The Sterling Forest is of clear Federal interest for permanent protection of the watershed, outdoor recreational activities, flora and fauna, and open space. Acquiring the forest is a cost-effective investment compared to the expenses of protecting the region's drinking water if the forest is developed. The Sterling Forest Reserve in New York is established to protect the watershed, wildlife, and recreational resources in the region. Federal funding is authorized for acquisition costs, and the management will be overseen by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "Commission" refers to the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, "Reserve" means the Sterling Forest Reserve, and "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Sterling Forest Reserve in New York is established by the Commission upon acquiring enough lands. The Reserve consists of approximately 17,500 acres as depicted on a map available for public inspection. The Secretary will transfer funds for land acquisition. The Commission must agree to specific terms and conditions before receiving federal funds for land acquisition within the Sterling Forest Reserve in New York. These conditions include managing acquired lands in accordance with the Act, obtaining owner consent for acquisitions, and conveying fee title to the United States if management is not consistent with the Act. The Commission must acquire National Park Service Wilderness Easement Lands and Conservation Easement Lands within the Sterling Forest Reserve using federal funds, and convey them to the United States within 30 days. The Commission must convey conservation easements on National Park Service Wilderness Easement Lands and Conservation Easement Lands to the United States to protect their wilderness character and restrict development compatible with the Appalachian National Scenic. The Commission must ensure that any development and use of the property is in line with the protection of the Appalachian National Scenic Trail and the general management plan. Funds for the Commission can only be transferred if matched by non-Federal sources. The Commission is responsible for managing lands within the Reserve in line with its authorities and the Act's purposes. A general management plan must be prepared within 3 years for approval by the Secretary. Appropriations are authorized for the Act's implementation, with a limit of $17,500,000 for land acquisition within the Reserve.
